title: goroutine memory leak
body:
#19865 ## System information

Geth version: `geth version 1.9.0-stable`
OS & Version: Linux

#### Expected behaviour

Not going out-of-memory

#### Actual behaviour

I'm using go-ethereum in a golang project and I have some problems when testing with Ginkgo and using `backends.NewSimulatedBackend` with the following function:

```

func (s *SmartContract) SetupSimulatedBlockchain() {
	key, _ := crypto.GenerateKey()
	auth := bind.NewKeyedTransactor(key)
	alloc := make(core.GenesisAlloc)
	balance := new(big.Int)
	balance.SetString("10000000000000000000", 10) // 10 eth in wei
	alloc[auth.From] = core.GenesisAccount{Balance: balance}

	auth.Value = big.NewInt(0) // in wei
	auth.GasLimit = defaultGasLimit
	auth.GasPrice = big.NewInt(0)

	blockchain := backends.NewSimulatedBackend(alloc, defaultGasLimit)
	instance := s.deployContract(auth, blockchain)

	blockchain.Commit()

	s.API = &DocumentHashSession{
		Contract: instance,
		CallOpts: bind.CallOpts{
			Pending: true,
			From:    auth.From,
			Context: context.Background(),
		},
		TransactOpts: *auth,
	}
}
```
The problem is that in my application I'm initializing the backend/Blockchain for every test (BeforeEach) and this gets a problem in the CI/CD environment with the goroutines (see stack trace). I'm not reusing it in the tests because after some transaction I get a "gas limit reached" message

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

In my machine I do not have the error but in the CI/CD environment, I do. Any examples or ideas for testing this kind of operations? Thanks in advance

Yeah, an internal loop goroutine was added to the blockchain, so now it needs to be cleaned up properlty. We need a `Close` method on the simulated backend to call `Close` on blockchain.
The goroutine leak was fixed by https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/19902 (you can call `Close()` on your simualted backends now when you're done). Could you check if this solves your issue?
No complaint for more than 6 months now, I assume the memory leak was successfully fixed.
